commit_message:
Use tripleo-image-serve role name for train

For train jobs use role name as "tripleo-image-serve".
For releases later than Ussuri use "tripleo_image_serve" as
in Ussuri release role name is changed to tripleo_image_serve.

Change-Id: Id1e3d05606b1f15b600fd8a069434a6dca27762e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci refs/changes/65/721165/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: set tripleo image serve role name for train set_fact: tripleo_image_serve_role: tripleo-image-serve when: (release is defined and release == 'train') or (branch_override is defined and branch_override == 'stable/train') name: "{{ tripleo_image_serve_role | default('tripleo_image_serve') }}"

commit_message:
Cleanup py27 support

This repo is now testing only with Python 3, so let's make
a few cleanups:
- Remove python 2.7 stanza from setup.py
- Add requires on python >= 3.6 to setup.cfg so that pypi and pip
  know about the requirement
- Remove obsolete sections from setup.cfg
- Update classifiers
- Update requirements, no need for python_version anymore
- Switch to using sphinx-build with warnings enabled, fix
  warnings found with autodoc
- Cleanup doc/source/conf.py to remove now obsolete content.
- Use newer openstackdocstheme version, switch to using apidoc
- Remove install_command from tox.ini, the default is fine
- Change some imports to use python3 changed names

Change-Id: Ibb2e614c7db8a01e41caed8314c1d46479c78295

commit_message:
Use unittest.mock instead of third party mock

Now that we no longer support py27, we can use the standard library
unittest.mock module instead of the third party mock lib.

Change-Id: I9357128c04f2fe0284432c1f6a543d63309efda3
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Adding Tim Burke candidacy for Swift

Change-Id: Iddbea5bb8a71d2ddf3c6ad4fd785baeae2b8dea5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/election refs/changes/79/716379/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: It would be my honor and pleasure to continue serving you as Swift PTL. The world continues to generate and retain ever-increasing amounts of data, and Swift continues to rise to the challenge of storing that data durably and making it highly available. I'm excited to help us engineer now to be ready for next year's data-center demands. To that end, there are several projects we'll be advancing; in general, these are not short-term, though some pieces will surely come in the next cycle. As hard-drive sizes increase, the lots-of-small-files problem has become a lots-of-files problem. Between 16TB hard drives hitting the market and cost concerns pushing us toward ever more drives per box, even historically "reasonable" object sizes are producing noticeable memory pressure that we'd like to reduce. OVH's explorations in this space give us all a leg up that we should take advantage of. As clusters grow, we must ensure Swift can scale with them. Some aspects of that will be relatively straight-forward, like allowing rings to support more than 64k devices. Other challenges are less well-defined; there are likely improvements that could be made in replication and backend protocols, for example, but there is no single way forward. There will likely be some experiments that never land on master -- but as long as they are in the open and we can all learn from them, they will not be failures. All of that must be driven by what we learn by operating real clusters at scale. To do that, we must improve our metrics and monitoring, and find ways to observe the system dynamically. Post-facto log analysis is not tenable when dealing with tens of thousands of requests per second across hundreds of nodes. At the same time, we cannot neglect our client ecosystem. This extends not just to python-swiftclient, but to S3 clients as well. For better or worse, S3 has become the de facto standard interface for object storage, and we must ensure our compatibility is as seamless as possible. This cycle we added S3-compatible versioning, but there is so much more we could be doing, from object life-cycle management to bucket inventories. As always, we will listen to our users and prioritize addressing their pain points. Tim Burke

commit_message:
Stop configuring install_command in tox.

Currently, we are overriding 'install_command' to use 'pip'. This is
considered poor behavior and 'python -m pip' should be used instead:

https://snarky.ca/why-you-should-use-python-m-pip/

It turns out that this is the the default value provided by tox:

https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-install_command

So we can remove the line and simply use the default value.

openstack-discuss thread
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-April/014237.html

Bumping the following libs in lower-constraints to avoid version
conflict:
-osprofiler 2.3.0
-python-keystoneclient to 3.22.0
-python-cinderclient to 5.0.0

Change-Id: Id0049dea1e16f9c459e7e63e5f7d96666fff708a

commit_message:
Update wording on tc roster

As the end date of a term is fluctuating, it's probably easier
to mention the elected date of each of the TC members, and users
can do the math.

This should clarify things.

commit_message:
PowerMax Driver - Compression Change Bug Fix

This fix makes changes to compression change checks that
account for scenarios that do not have a service_level
key present in the extra_specs and gets the relevant
information from the pool_name instead.

Change-Id: I5deaf0b961378a3a18046bea97fc56e98c284f77
Closes-Bug: #1869731

commit_message:
Cleanup py27 support

This repo is now testing only with Python 3, so let's make
a few cleanups:
- Remove python 2.7 stanza from setup.py
- Remove obsolete sections from setup.cfg
- Update classifiers
- Switch to using sphinx-build, switch to use
  openstackdocstheme and update requirements

Change-Id: I67ba5ceb1728ee16b866ecf1b71cbf545a01b7d9

commit_message:
[Fullstack] Handle properly BrokenPipeError exception

NetcatTester class should handle BrokenPipeError exception
and not raise it to fail test immediately if nc process wasn't
yet started when it tries first time to read/write something to
it.

Change-Id: Ica953cc2038b24c4b3985447b393763912aa6abd
Closes-Bug: #1871908
(cherry picked from commit c92950b0eea55b8f16ae4ecea9366dba4419545a)

commit_message:
[Fullstack] Handle properly BrokenPipeError exception

NetcatTester class should handle BrokenPipeError exception
and not raise it to fail test immediately if nc process wasn't
yet started when it tries first time to read/write something to
it.

commit_message:
[Fullstack] Handle properly BrokenPipeError exception

NetcatTester class should handle BrokenPipeError exception
and not raise it to fail test immediately if nc process wasn't
yet started when it tries first time to read/write something to
it.

Change-Id: Ica953cc2038b24c4b3985447b393763912aa6abd
Closes-Bug: #1871908
(cherry picked from commit c92950b0eea55b8f16ae4ecea9366dba4419545a)

commit_message:
[Fullstack] Handle properly BrokenPipeError exception

NetcatTester class should handle BrokenPipeError exception
and not raise it to fail test immediately if nc process wasn't
yet started when it tries first time to read/write something to
it.

Change-Id: Ica953cc2038b24c4b3985447b393763912aa6abd
Closes-Bug: #1871908
(cherry picked from commit c92950b0eea55b8f16ae4ecea9366dba4419545a)

"conf we recommend you to use ``backup_driver_stats_polling_interval`` to " "avoid deprecation warnings in logs." msgid ""msgid "" "In the Image service (Glance), the ``compressed`` container format " "identifier does not indicate a particular compression technology; it is up " "to the image consumer to determine what compression has been used, and there " "is no requirement that OpenStack services must support arbitrary compression " "technologies. "RBD driver has added multiattach support. It should be noted that " "replication and multiattach are mutually exclusive, so a single RBD volume " "can only be configured to support one of these features at a time. " "Additionally, RBD image features are not preserved which prevents a volume " "being retyped from multiattach to another type. This limitation is temporary " "and will be addressed soon." msgstr "" "RBD driver has added multiattach support. commit_message:
Update HACKING document to match current checks

The HACKING document had gotten out of date with a few removals and
additions of hacking checks. This gets it synced up with the current
state of our checks.

Change-Id: I8ace7662bb11d5708dd507b79f4a2476c9875ac5
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/74/716774/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - [C303] Ensure that there are no 'print()' statements are used in code that should be using LOG calls.- [C336] Must use a dict comprehension instead of a dict constructor with a sequence of key-value pairs. - [C337] Ensure the standard library mock modules is used and not the third party mock library that was needed for Python 2 support.
deleted_lines: - [N336] Must use a dict comprehension instead of a dict constructor with a sequence of key-value pairs.- [C302] six.text_type should be used instead of unicode. - [C303] Ensure that there are no 'print()' statements in code that is being committed. - [C304] Enforce no use of LOG.audit messages. LOG.info should be used instead. - [C305] Prevent use of deprecated contextlib.nested.- [C307] LOG.warn is deprecated. Enforce use of LOG.warning.

subject: Use unittest.mock instead of third party mock
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-04-18 16:53:57.000000000', 'files': ['kuryr/tests/unit/segmentation_type_drivers/test_vlan.py', 'kuryr/tests/unit/binding/drivers/test_utils.py', 'kuryr/tests/unit/binding/drivers/test_nested.py', 'kuryr/tests/unit/binding/drivers/test_hw_veb.py', 'kuryr/tests/unit/binding/drivers/test_ipvlan.py', 'kuryr/tests/unit/test_opts.py', 'kuryr/tests/unit/test_utils.py', 'kuryr/tests/unit/binding/drivers/test_macvlan.py', 'kuryr/tests/unit/binding/drivers/test_veth.py', 'kuryr/tests/unit/binding/drivers/test_vlan.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kuryr/commit/0f47555b38569e847eee8c7bfad57d9b4034e244', 'message': 'Use unittest.mock instead of third party mock

Now that we no longer support py27, we can use the standard library
unittest.mock module instead of the third party mock lib.

Change-Id: Ibe31e2d17b8baf88c40e00e3beaa019b13594c7c
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Use unittest.mock instead of third party mock

Now that we no longer support py27, we can use the standard library
unittest.mock module instead of the third party mock lib.

Change-Id: Ibe31e2d17b8baf88c40e00e3beaa019b13594c7c
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kuryr refs/changes/27/720927/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Run Dockerfiles using Python, not 'docker build'
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-09-14 00:28:55.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla/commit/ce67650f785a84d0777169b9b08114191c635c3e', 'message': "(WIP) Example python script to run Dockerfiles

With the theory that since our Dockerfiles are not actually Docker-
specific (we should work with other runtimes at some point) and
in fact we're already processing from something non-buildfiley
via our templating mechanism, we want to move to building containers
using something that is not Docker specific.

As a first stage, this converts a Dockerfile to a set of scripts
that can work with 'docker run' to build the container.  At some
future point, this allows us to change our file format from the
standard Dockerfile to something with more useful directives and
better substitution.

Change-Id: I75c088bf52fb1de7d9244aee6f8d86e64fa43aea
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-09-14 15:57:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla/commit/74d301f80fd77e378e1b10171040fbb24bdd445f', 'message': "(WIP) Example python script to run Dockerfiles

commit_message:
Run Dockerfiles using Python, not 'docker build'

With the theory that since our Dockerfiles are not actually Docker-
specific (we should work with other runtimes at some point) and
in fact we're already processing from something non-buildfiley
via our templating mechanism, we want to move to building containers
using something that is not Docker specific.

As a first stage, this converts a Dockerfile to a set of scripts
that can work with 'docker run' to build the container.  At some
future point, this allows us to change our file format from the
standard Dockerfile to something with more useful directives and
better substitution.

The new option --fastbuild enables this build.  The system defaults
to the current behaviour.

Change-Id: I75c088bf52fb1de7d9244aee6f8d86e64fa43aea

commit_message:
Update docs building, Python 3 cleanup

Update docs building:
* Remove unneeded doc sections from setup.cfg
* Change constraints to use published document, use
  new variable
* Import mock from unittest, remove imports from future

Change-Id: I8f33d4c0bf5fcba203d410cd021c548219a757ec

commit_message:
Use unittest.mock instead of third party mock

Now that we no longer support py27, we can use the standard library
unittest.mock module instead of the third party mock lib.

Change-Id: If2df3ea9b3cbd2c9757dc22751de06932dad4757
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Update docs building

Update docs building:
* Switch to sphinx-build
* Update requirements for Sphinx and openstackdocstheme for
  python 3
* Remove unneeded doc and translation sections from setup.cfg

Change-Id: Ie6cae5b1e7b600a2b2396f403a8fa5a90e5f3463

commit_message:
Update graphlib to v2.1.7

This patch removes minified scripts from the repo too.

Added .zuul.yaml to get CI working.

Change-Id: Ie81b61e2f61678892ed8c81a8ae018ad42da9cff

commit_message:
[Trivial] Doc update on the stable-interface-names

Consistent interface naming is helpful in collecting introspection
data and final instance system.

Change-Id: I8d434f7f8412734a540b797255abb6391325f434
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-python-agent-builder refs/changes/72/720872/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Consistent Network Interface Naming ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Base cloud images normally have disabled consistent network interface naming by inserting an empty udev rule. Include ``stable-interface-names`` element if you want to have consistent network interface naming whenever it is required for instance image or deploy image. .. code-block:: bash ironic-python-agent-builder -e stable-interface-names --release 8 centos-minimal

commit_message:
Use unittest.mock instead of third party mock

Now that we no longer support py27, we can use the standard library
unittest.mock module instead of the third party mock lib.

Change-Id: I76e01d55ff4d9095a6dbf520752042824225de73
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/osprofiler refs/changes/69/720969/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Use unittest.mock instead of third party mock

commit_message:
Cleanup py27 support

This repo is now testing only with Python 3, so let's make
a few cleanups:
- Remove python 2.7 stanza from setup.py
- Add requires on python >= 3.6 to setup.cfg so that pypi and pip
  know about the requirement
- Remove obsolete sections from setup.cfg
- Update classifiers
- Update requirements, no need for python_version anymore
- Cleanup */source/conf.py to remove now obsolete content.
- Use newer openstackdocstheme, reno, Sphinx, hacking versions
  for python3
- Add pytest as requirement, horizon does not provide this anymore and
  the tests here call horizon files that need it.

Change-Id: I5983a19cadb210d55c30107fb963cfeaae0f1ee9

commit_message:
Python 3 library is needed for uWSGI.

Since Train Python 3 is used by default and running uWSGI requires then
Python 3 libraries.

commit_message:
Fix dashboard certificates skipping pkcs12 bundles

Octavia dashboard was skipping pkcs12 bundles when presenting
certificate options for TERMINATED_TLS listeners.
This patch corrects that so that users can select pkcs12 bundles
for use on their listeners.

Change-Id: I83687ed1476a9e413ca6a8a880dd31783450df67
Story: 2005436
Task: 30476

commit_message:
Migrate from ujson to simplejson

Additionally, temporarily set build-monasca-docker-image as non-voting
due to problems with buggy confluent-kafka 1.4.0 release, which prevents
building the Docker image.

Change-Id: I561ea633a09eb3d7468d2d55aa46d6fb3b2380ff
Story: 2007549
Task: 39390

commit_message:
Update connection info in pre_live_migration

Connection info stays attaching after live
migration and other info such device path
is lost. To make info consistent, update
connection info when attachment complete
is done

Change-Id: Ifb4decb2cf6023dcf026998c7515f850a4aee201
Close-Bug: #1870866

ensure centos-7 train image builds are tested

use a branched job to ensure build-image changes
do not impact older branches.  tripleo-ci is not
branched, so this coverage must be added.

subject: Add recreate test for bug 1855927
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-01-09 15:53:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/4174ef20370c5f999a5d488286ebf7cfdda7929e', 'message': 'Add recreate test for bug 1855927

When _poll_unconfirmed_resizes runs, if the actual resize
confirm fails on the source host the migration status may
be stuck in "confirming" status if it never reached the
source compute. Subsequent runs of _poll_unconfirmed_resizes
will not be able to auto-confirm the resize nor will the user
be able to manually confirm the resize. An admin could reset
the status on the server to ACTIVE or ERROR but that means
the source compute never gets cleaned up since you can only
confirm or revert a resize on a server with VERIFY_RESIZE status.

This adds a functional recreate test for the bug.

Note that if the request does get to the source compute and fails,
the _error_out_instance_on_exception context manager should set
the instance to ERROR status and the errors_out_migration decorator
should set the migration status to "error". The problem is if we
never get that far we can't recover automatically or via the API
without operator intervention.

Change-Id: I93e27d907a237ae16b6b4c7202ad157b067aa30e
Related-Bug: #1855927

commit_message:
Add recreate test for bug 1855927

When _poll_unconfirmed_resizes runs, if the actual resize
confirm fails on the source host the migration status may
be stuck in "confirming" status if it never reached the
source compute. Subsequent runs of _poll_unconfirmed_resizes
will not be able to auto-confirm the resize nor will the user
be able to manually confirm the resize. An admin could reset
the status on the server to ACTIVE or ERROR but that means
the source compute never gets cleaned up since you can only
confirm or revert a resize on a server with VERIFY_RESIZE status.

This adds a functional recreate test for the bug.

Note that if the request does get to the source compute and fails,
the _error_out_instance_on_exception context manager should set
the instance to ERROR status and the errors_out_migration decorator
should set the migration status to "error". The problem is if we
never get that far we can't recover automatically or via the API
without operator intervention.

Conflicts:
    nova/tests/functional/test_servers.py

NOTE(lyarwood): Conflicts as I8c96b337f32148f8f5899c9b87af331b1fa41424
is not present on stable/train.

Change-Id: I93e27d907a237ae16b6b4c7202ad157b067aa30e
Related-Bug: #1855927
(cherry picked from commit 95c9d710dd6a06b8d2fcd941343075872cdf95d5)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/56/701756/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_utils import fixture as osloutils_fixturefrom nova.tests.unit import cast_as_callclass PollUnconfirmedResizesTest(integrated_helpers.ProviderUsageBaseTestCase): """Tests for the _poll_unconfirmed_resizes periodic task.""" compute_driver = 'fake.MediumFakeDriver' def setUp(self): super(PollUnconfirmedResizesTest, self).setUp() # Start two computes for the resize. self._start_compute('host1') self._start_compute('host2') def test_source_host_down_during_confirm(self): """Tests the scenario that between the time that the server goes to VERIFY_RESIZE status and the _poll_unconfirmed_resizes periodic task runs the source compute service goes down so the confirm task fails. """ server = self._build_minimal_create_server_request( name='test_source_host_down_during_confirm', image_uuid=nova.tests.unit.image.fake.get_valid_image_id(), networks='none', host='host1') server = self.api.post_server({'server': server}) server = self._wait_for_state_change(server, 'ACTIVE') # Cold migrate the server to the other host. self.api.post_server_action(server['id'], {'migrate': None}) server = self._wait_for_state_change(server, 'VERIFY_RESIZE') self.assertEqual('host2', server['OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:host']) # Make sure the migration is finished. self._wait_for_migration_status(server, ['finished']) # Stop and force down the source compute service. self.computes['host1'].stop() source_service = self.api.get_services( binary='nova-compute', host='host1')[0] self.api.put_service( source_service['id'], {'status': 'disabled', 'forced_down': True}) # Now configure auto-confirm and call the method on the target compute # so we do not have to wait for the periodic to run. Also configure # the RPC call from the API to the source compute to timeout after 1 # second. self.flags(resize_confirm_window=1, rpc_response_timeout=1) # Stub timeutils so the DB API query finds the unconfirmed migration. future = timeutils.utcnow() + datetime.timedelta(hours=1) ctxt = context.get_admin_context() with osloutils_fixture.TimeFixture(future): # Use the CastAsCall fixture since the fake rpc is not going to # simulate a failure from the service being down. with cast_as_call.CastAsCall(self): self.computes['host2'].manager._poll_unconfirmed_resizes(ctxt) self.assertIn('Error auto-confirming resize', self.stdlog.logger.output) self.assertIn('No reply on topic compute', self.stdlog.logger.output) # FIXME(mriedem): This is bug 1855927 where the migration status is # left in "confirming" so the _poll_unconfirmed_resizes task will not # process it again nor can the user confirm the resize in the API since # the migration status is not "finished". self._wait_for_migration_status(server, ['confirming']) ex = self.assertRaises(client.OpenStackApiException, self.api.post_server_action, server['id'], {'confirmResize': None}) self.assertEqual(400, ex.response.status_code) self.assertIn('Instance has not been resized', six.text_type(ex)) # That error message is bogus because the server is resized. server = self.api.get_server(server['id']) self.assertEqual('VERIFY_RESIZE', server['status'])

commit_message:
Update master for stable/ussuri

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/ussuri.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/ussuri.

Change-Id: I8783d496616a77c3ec6d70c3295f3a17de0e7e80
Sem-Ver: feature

commit_message:
Mark MacroSAN Driver Supported

Add new optional features:
* Revert to snapshot
* MultiAttach
* Thin Provisioning
* Consistency Groups
* volume replication
* Qos
* Attach Snapshot
* Online Extend Support

The 3rd Party CI is running. Therefor, the driver is being marked
supported in 'U' release.

Change-Id: Ia26fa9763efd329d0be62e2c418322056f5b086d

subject: PoC: Docker multi-stage builds
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-01-17 21:23:30.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla/commit/9656da4c8e337c81d0ba1bc8fed9b0da72b97972', 'message': 'PoC: Docker multi-stage builds

Proof of concept: support multi-stage image builds for source images.

Multi-stage builds allow for smaller images, by installing build-time
dependencies in an intermediate image which is then discarded. The final
image contains only the product of the build process, which in the case
of kolla source images is typically the virtual environment.

The approach taken repurposes the openstack-base image as a base image
for intermediate stage builder images. It fits this purpose well since
it mostly adds python build dependencies and the kolla virtual
environment.

A new image, openstack-base-source (name could be better), is used as
the base image for final stage images, and contains the few packages
from openstack-base that are actually required at runtime.

The new hierarchy is as follows:

base -> openstack-base -> glance-base (stage 1)
base -> openstack-base-source -> glance-base (stage 2) -> glance-api

Currently this has only been implemented for Glance images.

The current approach results in a significant reduction in the image
size:

REPOSITORY                                TAG                   SIZE
kolla/centos-source-glance-api            single-stage-glance   917MB
kolla/centos-source-glance-registry       single-stage-glance   871MB
kolla/centos-source-glance-base           single-stage-glance   871MB
kolla/centos-source-glance-api              multi-stage-glance  763MB
kolla/centos-source-glance-base             multi-stage-glance  721MB
kolla/centos-source-glance-registry         multi-stage-glance  721MB

The savings come from not including the python build dependencies or
source code in the final image.

The design could probably be improved upon.

Change-Id: Id4955dc547748ec5bf620fd106115a63ab3a6495

commit_message:
PoC: Docker multi-stage builds

Proof of concept: support multi-stage image builds for source images.

Multi-stage builds allow for smaller images, by installing build-time
dependencies in an intermediate image which is then discarded. The final
image contains only the product of the build process, which in the case
of kolla source images is typically the virtual environment.

The approach taken repurposes the openstack-base image as a base image
for intermediate stage builder images. It fits this purpose well since
it mostly adds python build dependencies and the kolla virtual
environment.

A new image, openstack-base-source (name could be better), is used as
the base image for final stage images, and contains the few packages
from openstack-base that are actually required at runtime.

The new hierarchy is as follows:

base -> openstack-base -> glance-base (stage 1)
base -> openstack-base-source -> glance-base (stage 2) -> glance-api

Currently this has only been implemented for Glance images.

The current approach results in a significant reduction in the image
size:

REPOSITORY                                TAG                   SIZE
kolla/centos-source-glance-api            single-stage-glance   917MB
kolla/centos-source-glance-registry       single-stage-glance   871MB
kolla/centos-source-glance-base           single-stage-glance   871MB
kolla/centos-source-glance-api              multi-stage-glance  763MB
kolla/centos-source-glance-base             multi-stage-glance  721MB
kolla/centos-source-glance-registry         multi-stage-glance  721MB

The savings come from not including the python build dependencies or
source code in the final image.

The design could probably be improved upon.

Change-Id: Id4955dc547748ec5bf620fd106115a63ab3a6495

commit_message:
Get validation groups info from groups.yaml file

This patch makes the VALIDATION_GROUPS list constants dynamic by getting
them from the 'groups.yaml' file. This file comes from
tripleo-validations and is present on the Undercloud at the location [1].

[1] => /usr/share/openstack-tripleo-validations

Change-Id: Ide8cba32a0ea14086714094291f1a8866b669491
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud (Strider) <gchamoul@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit afb9887a408dc7ce4b178f730ea17f7c77f120b9)

commit_message:
Stop configuring install_command in tox.

Currently, we are overriding 'install_command' to use 'pip'. This is
considered poor behavior and 'python -m pip' should be used instead:

https://snarky.ca/why-you-should-use-python-m-pip/

It turns out that this is the the default value provided by tox:

https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-install_command

So we can remove the line and simply use the default value.

openstack-discuss thread
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-April/014237.html

Change-Id: Idda0a78f63d5bc3e8c9e56e042630c8d28db2162

commit_message:
Remove pypy job from x/surveil

x/surveil has not merged a single change since 2015, remove pypy job so
that the template can eventually get removed.

Change-Id: Icb5026ba4dfe7867fffd6bd5b06eee71acf4bce4

commit_message:
Move Ubuntu builds away from nb04

Something about the debootstrap processes destroys the nodepool
container, making not only this Ubuntu builds fail but then every
build after.

Move them back to regular builders while we debug further.

Change-Id: I48eb721bffafe2404a332192976848dba2ca80cc

container version.

commit_message:
Use unittest.mock instead of third party mock

Now that we no longer support py27, we can use the standard library
unittest.mock module instead of the third party mock lib.

Change-Id: I6a4524c3e0458747646995615535e85cde2e155f
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Cleanup py27 support

Make a few cleanups:
- Remove obsolete sections from setup.cfg
- Cleanup doc/source/conf.py to remove now obsolete content.
- Use newer openstackdocstheme version, update other needed
  requirements
- Remove install_command from tox.ini, the default is fine
- Update tox.ini for python3 support

Change-Id: I0c9f7ae65a8e1c1d7fec77e3958c54324213158b

commit_message:
add libvirt pqos spec

This spec propoposes adding support for static allocation of cache
and memory bandwidth limits to the libvirt virt driver.

blueprint libvirt-pqos
Change-Id: If2a5ec0e1c08d3a5d86f5cf1ba597611b3139774
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/64/662264/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================================== libvirt-platform-quality-of-service =================================== To run realtime workloads on commodity hardware effectively requires that the guest and host be tuned for deterministic low latency and high throughput. Typically this is done using the existing EPA features such as hugepages, CPU pinning and emulator thread policies on a realtime host kernel. If the host also runs non-realtime workloads or unoptimized workloads, the determinism afforded by the careful tuning of the guest can be undone due to noisy neighbor effects such as cache thrashing or memory bandwidth exhaustion. This spec seeks to address this via static allocation of cache and memory bandwidth limits via the flavor, leveraging placement for resource accounting and the NUMA topology filter for affinity. Problem description =================== Realtime workloads rely on deterministic cache latency, memory access time and bandwidth to fulfill their SLAs. Noisy neighbor effect from non-realtime workloads co-located on the same host can result in violation of realtime workloads SLAs, which can be mitigated via static allocation of cache and memory bandwidth to instances. Use Cases --------- As an operator, I want to be able to deploy a realtime workload on a host with other realtime and non-realtime workloads and achieve a deterministic level of performance. As an operator with a datacenter containing multiple generations of hardware, I want to normalize the performance profile of a flavor regardless of the host it lands on by restricting the amount of cache or memory bandwidth the guest can consume. Proposed change =============== .. note:: Throughout this spec we refer to enabling both static cache allocation and memory bandwidth limits. The primary feature is static management of cache and memory bandwidth limits is proposed as a stretch goal for Train. It is intended that both will be implemented in Train but a phased approach is proposed to complete cache allocation first followed by memory bandwidth limits. .. note:: This set of features are referred to as RDT or resource directory technology by Intel, the generic vendor-independent name is PQoS (Platform Quality of Service). The Zen 2-based AMD Epyc CPUs also support PQoS as of kernel 4.21. See https://lkml.org/lkml/2018/12/23/69 This spec proposes extending the libvirt virt driver to support static allocation of cacheways and enforcement of maximum memory bandwidth limits. delegation of discovery and enforcement to an external agent (RMD, CYBORG, cron job) will also be possible. This will be achieved at a high level by introducing five new standard resource classes: two for the class of service types and three for L3 cache, to model the capacity of each resource in placement. As memory bandwidth limits are a max limit not a min limit no bandwidth is actually allocated to an instance as such memory bandwidth will not be tracked as a consumable resource in placement and therefore no resource class will be added. Details of the modeling in placement are covered in the "Data model impact" section of this spec. Three new config options will be added to the libvirt virt driver, two to enable support for memory limits and cache allocation, and one to declare the reserved NUMA of cacheways for the host per cache region/NUMA node. .. code:: [libvirt] cache_allocation_support=true # true|false default(false) memory_bandwidth_limiting=true # true|false default(false) reserved_cacheways=2,0 #reserved cacheways per NUMA node The detail of the config parameters are specified in the "Other deployer impact" section of this spec. Two new compute capability traits will be added to indicate if a host support cache allocation or memory bandwidth limits based in the values of the config options. These new traits will be used in combination with a new request prefilter to ensure that we do not mix cache allocated instance and non cache allocated instances on the same host. similarly the same will be done for memory limits. To support internal management of cache and memory bandwidth the libvirt virt driver will be extended to discover the capacity and availability of both resources by parsing the XML returned by the libvirt capabilities API. The libvirt driver will also be extended to support generating the domain XML element to instruct libvirt to allocate cache and specify memory bandwidth limits via the ``cachetune`` and ``memorytune`` sub-elements of the ``cputune`` element. To support external management of cache and memory bandwidth, the libvirt driver ``update_provider_tree`` method will be modified to only report cache and memory bandwidth inventories if enable the config. .. note :: It is considered out of scope of this spec to define how the resource providers are created when cache and memory bandwidth are manged externally. They could be created manually using ``osc-placement``, statically via a YAML file + additional change to the compute agent or dynamically via the external agent directly calling the placement API. Two new flavor extra specs will be introduced to enable requesting bandwidth limits and cache allocations, ``hw:numa_cache`` and ``hw:numa_bandwidth``. These new extra spec will also support the dot notation supported by the other ``hw:numa_*`` extra specs to allow specifying cache and memory bandwidth per virtual NUMA node. For example, consider a guest with two virtual NUMA nodes, two cache ways per NUMA node and a limit per NUMA node of 10% of the host NUMA nodes bandwidth :: hw:numa_nodes=2 hw:numa_cache=4 hw:numa_bandwidth=10 Alternatively, consider a guest with two virtual NUMA nodes, with unbalanced CPUs, cache and memory:: flavor.cpu=8 flavor.ram=4096 hw:numa_nodes=2 hw:numa_cpus.0=2 hw:numa_cpus.1=6 hw:numa_mem.0=1024 hw:numa_mem.1=3072 hw:numa_cache.0=2 hw:numa_cache.1=6 hw:numa_bandwidth.0=10 hw:numa_bandwidth.1=30 .. note :: The dot notation is supported for ``hw:numa_cache`` and ``hw:numa_bandwidth`` for parity with the existing ``hw:numa_cpus`` and ``hw:numa_mem`` options and because if you imbalance CPUs and memory it is likely that imbalanced cache and memory bandwidth will also be desired. It is expected that short form ``hw:numa_cache=X`` and ``hw:numa_bandwidth=Y`` will be used in most applications. Note the minimum allocation size of cache if specified is two cacheways per NUMA node. Each instance will consume one cache and memory class of service resource per NUMA node if either memory limits or cache allocation are requested. For hosts that support code and data partitioning of last level cache, ``hw:numa_code_cache`` and ``hw:numa_data_cache`` will be used instead of ``hw:numa_cache``. As code and data partitioning is a system-wide BIOS configuration, hosts with cache allocation enabled will either report inventories of ``L3_CACHE`` or inventories of ``L3_DATA_CACHE`` and ``L3_CODE_CACHE``. .. note:: As these extra specs affect the quantitative resources consumed by the instance, nova will not support equivalent properties for cache in the image metadata. As memory limits are not quantitative and do not consume resources they can optionally be supported in the image but that is left to the implementation to decide. .. note:: This feature will not be supported for non-NUMA guests. While libvirt and the kernel support specifying cache per process or per core the implementation in nova will be confined to NUMA instances to allow for static accounting of allocated cache and bandwidth. Cache and memory bandwidth are inherently linked to the memory subsystem on a host and therefore are significantly impacted by NUMA affinity. For this reason, and the accuracy limitation of the hardware, PQoS will only be supported for instances with ``hw:cpu_policy=dedicated``. Alternatives ------------ RMD could be used to manage cache and memory bandwidth via out of band of nova. A Cyborg driver for cache and memory bandwidth could be created. The operator could manually configure cache for the OS using the command line utility or ``resctrl`` virtual filesystem for RDT statically to restrict OS processes from being noisy neighbors to VMs. However, this does not help prevent noisy neighbor effect between VMs. We could use a static file to declare the inventories of cache, CoS policies and memory bandwidth instead of trying to discover it from libvirt. Data model impact ----------------- The libvirt driver will be extended to create one nested RP per cache region. On all current hardware that supports CAT there is a 1:1 mapping between cache region per NUMA node for L3 cache. The libvirt driver will also create one RP per memory controller with an inventory of bandwidth. The ``HostCell`` object will be extended to maintain a list of placement resource providers UUIDs per host cell. This will be used by the NUMA topology filter to ensure the NUMA affinity of the cache memory bandwidth, guest memory and guest CPUs. .. note:: If the NUMA affinity in placement spec is completed in train this feature will leverage the NUMA modeling support it introduces to track cache and memory banding per NUMA node. The approach described above is intended to facilitate this feature with our requiring a dependency on the new placement feature while also allowing a simple path to adopt the new feature in U via a reshape. This spec proposes introducing three new standard resource classes: - ``L3_DATA_CACHE`` - ``L3_CODE_CACHE`` - ``L3_UNIFIED_CACHE`` The units of the CACHE resource classes will be "cache ways". Each processor cache is divided into a number of cache ways each of which is approximately 1-1.2 MBs. A typical processor will have one cache way per physical core. If code and data prioritization is disabled it will have two cache ways, one of each type per physical core that are half the size. PQoS and CAT in particular works by restricting the cache way a process can write to but allows reads from all cache ways on the processor. CAT has a minimum requirement of two cache ways and a granularity thereafter of one cache way. In addition to the resource classes, above two additional resources class will be added to model the number of "Class of Service (COS)" or "Quality of Service (QoS)" policies supported by the CPU. - ``CACHE_COS`` - ``MEMORY_BANDWIDTH_COS`` The number of COS policies supported by a processor varies per SKU but is of the order of 8-16 COS polices, e.g. low double figures. As such it is possible to exhaust the number of COS policies available so they must be tracked as consumable resources. .. todo:: Add ascii diagram of resouce provider tree for a sample typical host. REST API impact --------------- This spec does not propose adding a new API or extending the existing APIs directly. However, this spec proposes introducing additional flavor extra spec to request cache allocation and memory bandwidth limits. ``hw:numa_cache`` Controls allocation of L3 unified cache ways. There is a minimum allocation of two cacheways per cache region/NUMA node with a granularity of one cache way. ``hw:numa_code_cache`` Controls allocation of L3 code cache ways. There is a minimum allocation of two cacheways per cache region/NUMA node with a granularity of one cache way. This may only be set if ``hw:numa_cache`` is not set. ``hw:numa_data_cache`` Controls allocation of L3 data cache ways. There is a minimum allocation of two cacheways per cache region/NUMA node with a granularity of one cache way.This may only be set if ``hw:numa_cache`` is not set. ``hw:numa_bandwidth`` Specifies the maximum memory bandwidth an instance can consume per NUMA node.This is set as a percentage of the total host NUMA node bandwidth. The granularity of this depend on the host but is typically increments of 10% with a minimum limit of 10%. .. note:: ``hw:numa_cache``, ``hw:numa_code_cache`` and ``hw:numa_data_cache`` also support the dot notation to specify the values per virtual NUMA node. If the standard form is used the allocations will be divided evenly between all guest NUMA nodes. It is an error to use the standard form if the minimum allocation of two cacheways per CoS is not possible or if the total allocation is not an integer multiple of the number of NUMA nodes specified by ``hw:numa_nodes``. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ This change will require the NUMA topology filter to be extended to consider cache affinity which many degrade the performance of that filter. This spec also proposes the introduction of a prefilter to transform the flavor request into placement requests. This prefilter will be disabled by default. When enabled, it will add a forbidden trait to the unnumbered request group when cache and/or bandwidth limits are not requested and will add a required trait and additional resource requests when they are. It is intended for this to increase scheduling performance by restricting the set of possible host by leveraging granular requests while also ensuring host are dynamically partitions such that no single host will be used for both cache allocated guests and guests without allocations. Other deployer impact --------------------- To enable this feature, four config options will be introduced, three of which will be set on the compute nodes and one that will be set on the scheduler: ``[libvirt] cache_allocation_support`` :Type: bool :Default: False :Description: When set to True enable reporting of cache allocation compute capability trait and cache resouce classes. This config option controls generation of cache allocation element in the domain XML. This value should be set to false on hosts that will not be used for cache confined guest or when cache allocation is enforce by an external agent. ``[libvirt] memory_bandwidth_limiting`` :Type: Boolean :Default: ``False`` :Description: When set to True enable reporting of memory bandwidth limiting compute capability trait. This config option also controls generation of ``memtune`` element in the domain XML. This value should be set to false on host that will not be used for memory bandwidth limited guests or when memory bandwidth is enforced by an external agent. ``[libvirt] reserved_cacheways`` :Type: List of ints :Default: ``[]`` :Description: Comma-separated list of reserved cacheways per NUMA node. For example, ``reserved_cacheways=2,2`` ``[scheduler] pqos_prefilter`` :Type: bool :Default: False :Description: When set to ``True``, enable transformation of cache and memory bandwidth extra specs into placement requests. Developer impact ---------------- This feature is related to NUMA and NUMA affinity and also introduces new resource classes that will be modeled in placement. As such this feature will need to evolve with the various other NUMA related change that are in-flight this cycle. To avoid a hard dependency on NUMA support in placement this spec proposes using the same mechanism of extending the HostCell object with a list for placement resource provider UUID so that we can track NUMA affinity of RPs in nova. This mechanism is also proposed for NUMA aware GPUs and is intended as a minimum change to the NUMA topology filter to enable NUMA affinity with placement until native support in developed in placement for NUMA-aware allocation candidate request. Similarly, as this spec introduces new NUMA-affined resources, the implementation will have to collaborate with the implementation of PCUs in placement, pMEM support and NUMA-aware vGPUS when extending the NUMA topology filter. Upgrade impact -------------- None. This feature will be disabled by default, meaning there is no initial upgrade impact. When this feature is enabled, new inventories will be created in nested resource providers beneath the compute node. On upgrade from Train to a release that supports NUMA affinity natively in placement, these resources will need to be reshaped to be children of the NUMA RPs. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: sean-k-mooney? Other contributors: sean-k-mooney? Work Items ---------- - Add new standard resource classes - Add new standard traits - Extend libvirt driver config options - Extend libvirt driver to discover and report inventories of cache - Extend libvirt driver XML generation for cache and memory limits - Add PQoS request prefilter - Update admin docs https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/ Dependencies ============ libvirt - 4.1.0 for the ``cachetune`` element - 4.7.0 for the ``memorytune`` element kernel - 4.10 for Intel CAT - 4.18 for Intel MBA - 4.21 for AMD Live migration support depends on https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/train/approved/numa-aware-live-migration.html Testing ======= This feature cannot be tested in the upstream gate via tempest as it depends on hardware that cannot be virtualized. As such this will be tested with unit and functional tests only. Documentation Impact ==================== The primary documentation for this feature will be in the admin guide. References ========== Intel® 64 and IA-32 ArchitecturesSoftware Developer’s Manual section on RDT - https://software.intel.com/sites/default/files/managed/39/c5/325462-sdm-vol-1-2abcd-3abcd.pdf#G55.100024 - https://github.com/torvalds/linux/blob/master/Documentation/x86/resctrl_ui.rst - https://github.com/intel/intel-cmt-cat/wiki/FAQ#how-to-find-intel-rdt-hardware-and-software-capabilities - https://software.intel.com/en-us/articles/cache-allocation-technology-telco-nfv-noisy-neighbor-experiments - https://www.intel.com/content/dam/www/public/us/en/documents/white-papers/increasing-platform-determinism-pqos-dpdk-paper.pdf Libvirt references - https://github.com/libvirt/libvirt/blob/0ec6343a069b21178d4580688a8380dbb6d76620/tests/vircaps2xmldata/vircaps-x86_64-resctrl.xml - https://github.com/libvirt/libvirt/blob/0ec6343a069b21178d4580688a8380dbb6d76620/tests/vircaps2xmldata/vircaps-x86_64-resctrl-cdp.xml - https://github.com/libvirt/libvirt/blob/0ec6343a069b21178d4580688a8380dbb6d76620/tests/vircaps2xmldata/vircaps-x86_64-resctrl-skx-twocaches.xml - https://github.com/libvirt/libvirt/blob/76be4f5ddac608873378e5bc43eb12731f7ddcf2/tests/vircaps2xmldata/vircaps-x86_64-resctrl.xml .. note:: ``max_allocations`` refers to the number of COS profiles, ``granularity`` refers to the cache way size, the minimum number of cache ways is ``2 * granularity``, and cache way associativity means the size/granularity which is equal to the number of total physical cores on a CPU package, not the enabled cores on a CPU package. History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Train - Introduced

commit_message:
VNF LCM API ETSI NFV-SOL specification update

Following points are updated:-

1. Removed 'scaleStatus' as it is not supported.
2. Added DB columns 'instantiation_level_id', 'additional_params'
   and 'task_state'. Explained the need of introducing 'task_state'.

Implements: bp/support-etsi-nfv-specs
Change-Id: I20f04fb08602f8d743efd483c9079b19740759c4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tacker-specs refs/changes/72/717172/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Add task_state to perform atomic operation on vnf instances ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Add ``task_state`` to the ``vnf_instances`` db table. The main purpose of introducing ``task_state`` is to allow actions to be performed on VNF in atomic way. Meaning, if you are instantiating a VNF, it won't allow you to perform same action or any other action on the VNF until that operation is complete. If user attempts to instantiate it again before completing the previous request, it will reject that request with 400 error. Types of ``task_state``: * INSTANTIATING: Set when a user calls instantiate API. After the VNF is instantiated completely, it will be set to None. If it fails to instantiate a VNF successfully, then it will be set to ``ERROR``. * HEALING: Set when a user calls heal API. After the VNF is healed completely, it will be set to None. If it fails to heal a VNF successfully, then it will be set to ``ERROR``. * TERMINATING: Set when a user calls terminate API. After the VNF is terminated completely, it will be set to None. If it fails to terminate a VNF successfully, then it will be set to ``ERROR``. * ERROR: An user won't be able to perform any actions on a VNF whose ``task_state`` is ``ERROR``. An Operator will need to fix all such issues manually. We plan to fix VNFs in such states using periodic tasks in future. `task_state` varchar(255) NULL `instantiation_level_id` varchar(255) NULL `additional_params` json NULL | >scaleStatus | ScaleInfo | 0..N | No | | | | GRACEFUL | | | At first, only forceful termination will be supported. |
deleted_lines: | >scaleStatus | ScaleInfo | 0..N | Yes | | | | | | | At first, only forceful termination will be supported. |

commit_message:
Update docs building

Update docs building:
* Switch to sphinx-build
* Update requirements for Sphinx and openstackdocstheme for
  python 3
* Remove unneeded doc and translation sections from setup.cfg
* Remove install_command, it's unneeded, the default is fine.

Change-Id: Ib9fe754b700bceb164ba0f596cbcc6d864ccbadc

Use unittest.mock instead of third party mock

commit_message:
Add support to build netcontrold binary image

netcontrold release supports rpm binary version.
Added support to build container with netcontrold rpm.

Change-Id: Idaaee886ceb6cf29494369e771f8ec453550e3f9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/23/704723/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: {% block openvswitch_netcontrold_release_version %} ENV openvswitch_netcontrold_version=1.0.13 ENV openvswitch_netcontrold_sha1sum=e5ca7e44af517e979bcf5d683e9995d0c9b40638 {% endblock %} {% if base_package_type == 'rpm' %} RUN curl -sSL -o /tmp/netcontrold.rpm https://github.com/netcontrold/netcontrold-py/releases/download/v${openvswitch_netcontrold_version}/netcontrold-${openvswitch_netcontrold_version}.noarch.rpm \ && echo "${openvswitch_netcontrold_sha1sum} /tmp/netcontrold.rpm" | sha1sum -c \ && yum -y install /tmp/netcontrold.rpm \ && rm -f /tmp/netcontrold.rpm {% else %}{% endif %}

commit_message:
Enable tripleo-image-serve in CentOS8

docker-distribution not available for C8, so
let's use tripleo-image-serve for registry usage.

Also collect httpd config and repo files for
debugging.

Change-Id: I0264d1c3d56995ed5dec6342a5f235936e807fe3

commit_message:
Use unittest.mock instead of third party mock

Now that we no longer support py27, we can use the standard library
unittest.mock module instead of the third party mock lib

Change-Id: I8426e378d1dfd40ba5312b10db2b04a540b65823

commit_message:
Implement 'selector-append' sass function

'selector-append' is used in xstatic-mdi [1] but it isn't supported by
the latest pyScss.
As a workaround we use 'append-selector' function from pyScss until
'selector-append' will be supported.

This patch also reverts Ia9e1e807591d4428f585177f521d4cb9d463b917
because we don't need it anymore.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/xstatic-mdi/src/tag/1.6.50.2/xstatic/pkg/mdi/data/scss/_functions.scss#L2

Change-Id: Ib8ca0fcfe339cb68d6a157a00cbc2d34854ef4c5
Closes-Bug: #1771559
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/77/719777/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: // NOTE(e0ne): it's temporary workaround to until specified function will // be supported by pyScss. We need to define this function before any MDI // usage. @function selector-append($selector, $to-append) { @return append-selector($selector, $to-append); }

commit_message:
Add VNF package update API

Added API to update information of VNF package.

Implemented below API:-

* PATCH /vnf_packages/{vnfPkgId}

Co-authored-by: Shubham Potale <shubham.potale@nttdata.com>
Change-Id: I6d60e87b48a6703362dcd30975f300f524f8ca7a
Implements: bp enhance-vnf-package-support-part1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tacker refs/changes/91/705891/11 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_db import exception as db_excfrom oslo_utils import excutils try: with db_api.context_manager.writer.using(context): new_entries = [] for key, value in user_data.items(): new_entries.append({"key": key, "value": value, "package_uuid": package_uuid}) if new_entries: context.session.execute( models.VnfPackageUserData.__table__.insert(None), new_entries) return user_data except db_exc.DBDuplicateEntry: # a concurrent transaction has been committed, # try again unless this was the last attempt with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception() as context: if attempt < max_retries - 1: context.reraise = False else: raise exceptions.UserDataUpdateCreateFailed( id=package_uuid, retries=max_retries) def _vnf_package_user_data_get_query(context, package_uuid, model): return api.model_query(context, model, read_deleted="no", project_only=True).\ filter_by(package_uuid=package_uuid) @db_api.context_manager.writer def _update_user_defined_data(context, package_uuid, user_data): model = models.VnfPackageUserData user_data = user_data.copy() session = context.session with session.begin(subtransactions=True): # Get existing user_data db_user_data = _vnf_package_user_data_get_query(context, package_uuid, model).all() save = [] skip = [] # We only want to send changed user_data. for row in db_user_data: if row.key in user_data: value = user_data.pop(row.key) if row.value != value: # ORM objects will not be saved until we do the bulk save row.value = value save.append(row) continue skip.append(row) # We also want to save non-existent user_data save.extend(model(key=key, value=value, package_uuid=package_uuid) for key, value in user_data.items()) # Do a bulk save if save: session.bulk_save_objects(save, update_changed_only=True) # Construct result dictionary with current user_data save.extend(skip) result = {row['key']: row['value'] for row in save} return resultdef _update_vnf_package_except_user_data(context, vnf_package): def _vnf_package_update(context, package_uuid, values, columns_to_join=None): user_data = values.pop('user_data', None) if user_data: _update_user_defined_data(context, package_uuid, user_data) vnf_package = _vnf_package_get_by_id( context, package_uuid, columns_to_join=columns_to_join) if values: vnf_package.update(values) _update_vnf_package_except_user_data(context, vnf_package)
deleted_lines: with db_api.context_manager.writer.using(context): new_entries = [] for key, value in user_data.items(): new_entries.append({"key": key, "value": value, "package_uuid": package_uuid}) if new_entries: context.session.execute( models.VnfPackageUserData.__table__.insert(None), new_entries)def _vnf_package_update(context, package_uuid, values, columns_to_join=None): vnf_package = _vnf_package_get_by_id(context, package_uuid, columns_to_join=columns_to_join) vnf_package.update(values)

subject: Add unique constraint on vnfd_id column
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-01-30 10:59:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tacker/commit/27a977922448d1a26b0b0df349b3cf36d1025a30', 'message': "WIP: Add unique constraint on vnfd_id column in vnf_package_vnfd

In Vnf LCM, when user will call create vnf instance API, vnfdId will be passed
in the CreateVnfRequest as per SOL002, section 5.5.2.3 [1]. Based on this vnfdId,
it will look for the vnf package to load the csar package at the time of
instantiating vnf instance. So it's important that vnfdId is unique in
the vnf_package_vnfd db table.

Added vnfd_id and deleted columns as unique key in vnf_package_vnfd db
table.

Change-Id: I2da2acf256bec307b606c5a152c0d47af24ad525
Blueprint: support-etsi-nfv-specs

commit_message:
Add unique constraint on vnfd_id column

In Vnf LCM, when user will call create vnf instance API, vnfdId
will be passed in the CreateVnfRequest as per SOL002,
section 5.5.2.3 [1]. Based on this vnfdId, it will look for the
vnf package to load the csar package at the time of instantiating vnf
instance. So it's important that vnfdId is unique in the
``vnf_package_vnfd`` dbb table.

Added ``vnfd_id`` and ``deleted`` columns as unique key in
``vnf_package_vnfd`` db table.

[1] : https://www.etsi.org/deliver/etsi_gs/NFV-SOL/001_099/002/02.06.01_60/gs_nfv-sol002v020601p.pdf

Change-Id: I2da2acf256bec307b606c5a152c0d47af24ad525
Blueprint: support-etsi-nfv-specs

commit_message:
Add vnflcm support base framework

Added vnflcm controller and router Rest API code.

Change-Id: I237f263df7eb41c0ca768869a8e5ce25637f13ca
Blueprint: support-etsi-nfv-specs
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tacker refs/changes/40/701940/18 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2019 OpenStack Foundation # # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import routes from tacker.api.vnflcm.v1 import controller as vnf_lcm_controller from tacker import wsgi class VnflcmAPIRouter(wsgi.Router): """Routes requests on the API to the appropriate controller and method.""" def __init__(self): mapper = routes.Mapper() super(VnflcmAPIRouter, self).__init__(mapper) def _setup_route(self, mapper, url, methods, controller, default_resource): all_methods = ['HEAD', 'GET', 'POST', 'PUT', 'PATCH', 'DELETE'] missing_methods = [m for m in all_methods if m not in methods.keys()] allowed_methods_str = ",".join(methods.keys()) for method, action in methods.items(): mapper.connect(url, controller=controller, action=action, conditions={'method': [method]}) if missing_methods: mapper.connect(url, controller=default_resource, action='reject', allowed_methods=allowed_methods_str, conditions={'method': missing_methods}) def _setup_routes(self, mapper): default_resource = wsgi.Resource(wsgi.DefaultMethodController(), wsgi.RequestDeserializer()) controller = vnf_lcm_controller.create_resource() # Allowed methods on /vnflcm/v1/vnf_instances resource methods = {"GET": "index", "POST": "create"} self._setup_route(mapper, "/vnf_instances", methods, controller, default_resource) # Allowed methods on # /vnflcm/v1/vnf_instances/{vnfInstanceId} resource methods = {"DELETE": "delete", "GET": "show"} self._setup_route(mapper, "/vnf_instances/{id}", methods, controller, default_resource) # Allowed methods on # /vnflcm/v1/vnf_instances/{vnfInstanceId}/instantiate resource methods = {"POST": "instantiate"} self._setup_route(mapper, "/vnf_instances/{id}/instantiate", methods, controller, default_resource) # Allowed methods on # /vnflcm/v1/vnf_instances/{vnfInstanceId}/terminate resource methods = {"POST": "terminate"} self._setup_route(mapper, "/vnf_instances/{id}/terminate", methods, controller, default_resource) # Allowed methods on # /vnflcm/v1/vnf_instances/{vnfInstanceId}/heal resource methods = {"POST": "heal"} self._setup_route(mapper, "/vnf_instances/{id}/heal", methods, controller, default_resource)

commit_message:
Use unittest.mock instead of third party mock

Now that we no longer support py27, we can use the standard library
unittest.mock module instead of the third party mock lib.

Change-Id: I4b70b6adbfef1f431bf367e3ee1e385604e38f9a
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Only add non-empty blacklisted hostnames.

This addresses an issue in CI where 'Controller!' is being passed as
the --limit host in the job:
tripleo-ci-centos-8-scenario000-multinode-oooq-container-updates

Change-Id: I0056fdbe3d9807e6baf4a1645a632ab9eb1b2668
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/76/719476/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ['!%s' % h for h in self.blacklisted_hostnames if h])

subject: Make nums_pcie_ports as a paratem
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-04-14 00:47:56.000000000', 'files': ['ansible/roles/nova-cell/defaults/main.yml', 'ansible/roles/nova-cell/templates/nova.conf.d/libvirt.conf.j2'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible/commit/3eac3c760d1d60a8bf16ec312c12e233bc539e78', 'message': 'Make nums_pcie_ports as a paratem

In Kolla Deployed Octavia, we need to mount more NICs to the vm,
which will induce that we run out all the slots of PCI and meet error:

attaching network adapter failed.: libvirt.libvirtError: internal error: No more available PCI slots

So we need to pre-set the nums_pcie_slots in nova.conf
Related change in Nova: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/545034/

Change-Id: I770c23540e41f6731979abc49bdda030634bbd07
Signed-off-by: Kevin Zhao <kevin.zhao@linaro.org>
'}]
commit_message:
Make nums_pcie_ports as a paratem

In Kolla Deployed Octavia, we need to mount more NICs to the vm,
which will induce that we run out all the slots of PCI and meet error:

attaching network adapter failed.: libvirt.libvirtError: internal error: No more available PCI slots

So we need to pre-set the nums_pcie_slots in nova.conf
Related change in Nova: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/545034/

Change-Id: I770c23540e41f6731979abc49bdda030634bbd07
Signed-off-by: Kevin Zhao <kevin.zhao@linaro.org>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/02/719702/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Support allowed_cidrs for Octavia listener

Support ``allowed_cidrs`` property for the resource ``OS::Octavia::Listener``,
the property is allowed to be updated as well. The property 'allowed_cidrs'
was introduced in Octavia since Train release. The default value is empty
list if it is not specified in Heat template.

Task: 38952
Story: 2007378

Change-Id: I9d38716b236b0782f0d09097b7a0f615fe5be041
(cherry picked from commit dd29c9508c7684a0badd6c29e09e0e63e9897e95)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/48/715748/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- features: - Support ``allowed_cidrs`` property for the resource ``OS::Octavia::Listener``, the property is allowed to be updated as well. The property 'allowed_cidrs' was introduced in Octavia since Train release. The default value is empty list if it is not specified in Heat template.

commit_message:
Update ldap-backend options

Several of the options defined in ldap_backend.pp were using duplicate
values already specified in keystone/conf/ldap.py. Instead of
duplicating the same value, we can set them to undefined and just let
the default values from keystone come through.

This commit also updates the values of use_pool and use_auth_pool to
True so they're consistent with the default values in keystone.

Co-Authored-By: Dave Wilde <dwilde@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I507d1b736dbbb147c67b9d399c033703b432b16d
(cherry picked from commit 1081ac51db7f560e5856809480fb98c215747476)
(cherry picked from commit e59b90669832d5bc20da2da0c0ac5ed9c16e656f)
(cherry picked from commit 2821509f0e7f67b711257d1621dfe28701b910aa)

commit_message:
PowerMax Driver - PowerMax Pools Fix

This change fixes bug 1873253 whereby live migration was broken
for volume-types with 'None' set as workload. The PowerMax for
Cinder driver now accounts for both 'None' and 'NONE' variations
of service level and workload.

Change-Id: Ia26993f8c352d539fa8834d368a9c39109d6485d
Closes-Bug: #1873253

commit_message:
Fix yaml dependency issue with dracut-regenerate for python3

This patch fixes a dependency issue where yaml package for python3 was
not being installed correctly because there was an install from
`package` flag assigned when diskimage-builder by default assumes
install from `source` inside packa-installs file for dracut-regenerate.
Additionally, `package-installs-squash` executable now has useful debug
info for packages that are skipped stating why they have been skipped.

Closes-Bug: #1760853
Change-Id: I3e583467347fec3a6d41380f9fffa865aa7c7586
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/97/558497/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
mariadb: add pynacl dependency to support ed25519

In order to support configuration of ed25519 authentication,
puppet-tripleo uses a python helper that depends on pynacl.

Update the kolla config override to install pynacl in the mariadb
image to support the ed25519 use case.

Change-Id: I908b2af6acce25dfb115463f9d04b0e14c7cba33
Related-Bug: #1866093
(cherry picked from commit 5ec5abb796c9d423f89b3093cb846d390453ad6a)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/68/719368/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # LP #1866093: auth_ed25519 currently requires puppet-tripleo to # call a python script depending on pynacl {% if distro_python_version.startswith('3') %} {% set mariadb_packages_append = mariadb_packages_append + ['python3-pynacl'] %} {% else %} {% set mariadb_packages_append = mariadb_packages_append + ['python2-pynacl'] %} {% endif %}

commit_message:
Use unittest.mock instead of third party mock

Now that we no longer support py27, we can use the standard library
unittest.mock module instead of the third party mock lib.

Change-Id: I89425273ad2092f5394f20c7cdecde14877b1a01
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

subject: Support the use of domain name as iSCSI portal.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-06-25 06:21:50.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/volume/drivers/inspur/as13000/as13000_driver.py', 'cinder/tests/unit/volume/drivers/inspur/as13000/test_as13000_driver.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/e31b09882835e449521045459dc7484a02e11ac9', 'message': 'Support the use of domain name as iSCSI portal.

AS13000 can create a domain name in the storage system to bind multiple
access IPs, which can be used to increase reliability instead of multipath.
As it is usually one domain name for a use case, we can use a configuration
option to keep the domain name.

Change-Id: I46d125c4ef06cac1260c92ef3e5b78ea2e845be4
'}]
commit_message:
Support the use of domain name as iSCSI portal.

AS13000 can create a domain name in the storage system to bind multiple
access IPs, which can be used to increase reliability instead of multipath.
As it is usually one domain name for a use case, we can use a configuration
option to keep the domain name.

Change-Id: I46d125c4ef06cac1260c92ef3e5b78ea2e845be4

commit_message:
Update docs building

Update docs building:
* Switch to sphinx-build
* Update requirements for Sphinx and openstackdocstheme for
  python 3
* Remove unneeded doc and translation sections from setup.cfg
* Remove install_command, it's unneeded, the default is fine.

Change-Id: I3d2e0459ba4aedf21c01d7725fe5ab266f9f4da3

commit_message:
Use unittest.mock instead of third party mock

Now that we no longer support py27, we can use the standard library
unittest.mock module instead of the third party mock lib.

Change-Id: I5b053a2c5ad1adaed9d3c6072ea7493ab4b8c1ca
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Update master for stable/ussuri

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/ussuri.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/ussuri.

Change-Id: Ia506af26cca82e96f157bc777521fd82d39a74f5
Sem-Ver: feature

commit_message:
kibana/debian: use upstream package on all architectures

Upstream kibana package ships x86_64 binaries of NodeJS. I usually
repacked package without them to have something for other architectures.

Instead let us install upstream. Then on non-x86 archs we add nodejs
from distribution and remove x86-64 binaries.

Change-Id: Ia9feac726a60250215b1bc78bf90dc68ac6f956a

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

specs repo either has py27 job or requirement or tox env.

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Change-Id: I3e97d60bd490e42c1ae29da356db59caa6994311

commit_message:
Cleanup py27 support

Make a few cleanups:
- Remove python 2.7 stanza from setup.py
- Add requires on python >= 3.6 to setup.cfg so that pypi and pip
  know about the requirement
- Remove obsolete sections from setup.cfg:
  * Wheel is not needed for python 3 only repo
  * Some other sections are obsolete
- Update classifiers

Change-Id: If1bd950d159a583d912d13e73113dae7f577e8eb

commit_message:
Move `ansible-playbook-command.sh` to the configured output directory

This change moves the `ansible-playbook-command.sh` script to the client configured
output directory so that should the client run into playbook execution issues the
script generated will be placed into a location known to exist, and be writable by
the executing user.

Closes-Bug: #1869762

Change-Id: I6f6be59efcaefbd351efa779075c881948663db9
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Cleanup python 2.7 support

* Remove six usage
* Remove python 2.7 stanza from setup.py
* Update supported python versions in setup.cfg
* Remove i18n related sections in setup.cfg
  as tempest-horizon has no translation support
* Remove unused requirements (oslo_log and babel) from requirements.txt

Change-Id: Ifd530546bfb5ae25e01e72a0e3c02f963d9d04d2

commit_message:
Update tox.ini

* Move basepython to [testenv] which is a place to define common things
* Move upper-constraints from install_command to deps
* Update the min version to 2.0 to allow http links in deps
* Cleanup unused tox envs ('cover' and 'debug')
* Drop unnecessary envs from envlist (only pep8 is used now)

Change-Id: Ie915a93b824331407a48affcbd31076d6a7cccfa

commit_message:
Drop sphinx document

We don't provide any sphinx documents as we cover horizon specific
topics in the horizon repository. The current version is just from
the cookiecutter and is never maintained since created.
README and CONTRIBUTING.rst would be enough.

Change-Id: I60c6e64e771f4e6bd3482a4d6a2a37228dde98b9

commit_message:
Use unittest.mock instead of third party mock

Now that we no longer support py27, we can use the standard library
unittest.mock module instead of the third party mock lib.

Change-Id: I27db1ac7f816f0f53b7ab0a10b48bf4c3c365a65
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
